<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 380, 146]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSEâ„¢

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 171, 184, 189]]<|/det|>
PHYSICS Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[869, 172, 908, 186]]<|/det|>
0625/22

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[734, 193, 908, 209]]<|/det|>
February/March 2025 45 minutes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 248, 507, 266]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 279, 438, 296]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 304, 540, 323]]<|/det|>
Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 336, 231, 353]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 351, 603, 379]]<|/det|>
- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. - For each question there are four possible answers \(\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}, \mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\). Choose the one you consider correct

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 380, 682, 397]]<|/det|>
and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet. - Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 413, 277, 430]]<|/det|>
- Write in soft pencil. - Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 441, 521, 459]]<|/det|>
spaces provided unless this has been done for you. - Do not use correction fluid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 472, 366, 489]]<|/det|>
- Do not write on any bar codes. - You may use a calculator.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 503, 680, 524]]<|/det|>
- Take the weight of 1.0 kg to be 9.8 N (acceleration of free fall \(=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\) ).

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 546, 222, 563]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION - The total mark for this paper is 40 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 579, 443, 594]]<|/det|>
- Each correct answer will score one mark. - Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 548, 91]]<|/det|> 1 The diagram shows three forces acting on an object. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[338, 103, 659, 179]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 197, 653, 212]]<|/det|> What is the magnitude of the resultant force acting on the object? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 224, 198, 238]]<|/det|> A \(\quad 2.0 \mathrm{~N}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[334, 224, 363, 238]]<|/det|> B 10 N <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 224, 526, 238]]<|/det|> C \(\quad 14 \mathrm{~N}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 224, 693, 238]]<|/det|> D \(\quad 16 \mathrm{~N}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 269, 440, 286]]<|/det|> 2 Which row defines speed and velocity? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 297, 758, 427]]<|/det|>
speed
velocity
A
distance travelled in a given direction
speed per unit time
B
distance travelled per unit time
speed in a given direction
C
distance travelled in a given direction
speed in a given direction
D
distance travelled per unit time
speed per unit time
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 454, 501, 471]]<|/det|> 3 The graph shows the journey of a motorcyclist. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 484, 918, 500]]<|/det|> Which section of the graph shows the time when the motorcyclist is stationary at some traffic lights? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 526, 690, 683]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 769, 91]]<|/det|> 4 The acceleration of free fall on the Moon has one sixth of its value on the Earth. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 584, 120]]<|/det|> On the Earth, an astronaut's mass is measured as 60 kg . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 824, 150]]<|/det|> Which row gives the mass and weight of the astronaut on the Earth and on the Moon? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 162, 555, 333]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 154, 237, 169]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 178, 153, 195]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 204, 153, 221]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 230, 153, 247]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 256, 153, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 281, 153, 298]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 307, 153, 323]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 357, 529, 376]]<|/det|> 5 The load-extension graph for a material is shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 388, 515, 405]]<|/det|> Which point indicates the limit of proportionality? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[338, 418, 659, 594]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 622, 753, 639]]<|/det|> 6 An object of mass 4.0 kg is moving with a velocity of \(3.0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) in a straight line. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 652, 427, 667]]<|/det|> What is the momentum of the object? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 679, 253, 694]]<|/det|> A \(\quad 0.75 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 679, 410, 694]]<|/det|> B \(\quad 1.3 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 679, 572, 694]]<|/det|> C \(\quad 12 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 679, 736, 694]]<|/det|> D \(\quad 24 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
7 A tall cylinder is partly filled with two liquids, which do not mix. The two liquids have different densities. A student measures the pressure due to the liquids at different depths.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[300, 115, 697, 277]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 290, 766, 305]]<|/det|>
Which graph shows how the liquid pressure varies between positions P and Q ?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 318, 840, 622]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 652, 657, 669]]<|/det|>
8 A tennis ball with momentum \(2.3 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) is struck by a tennis racket.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 683, 637, 698]]<|/det|>
The racket causes the direction of motion of the ball to reverse.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 712, 918, 728]]<|/det|>
The racket exerts an average force of 1500 N during the impact with the ball. The racket and ball are in contact with each other for a time of 0.0024 s .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 757, 788, 773]]<|/det|>
What is the magnitude of the momentum of the ball as it leaves the tennis racket?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 785, 240, 801]]<|/det|>
A \(1.3 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 785, 410, 801]]<|/det|>
B \(3.6 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 785, 576, 801]]<|/det|>
C \(5.9 \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 785, 742, 801]]<|/det|>
D \(8.6 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 446, 91]]<|/det|>
9 A car is travelling at a speed of \(8.0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 504, 120]]<|/det|>
The kinetic energy stored in the car is 32000 J .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 778, 150]]<|/det|>
What is the kinetic energy stored in the car when its speed increases to \(16 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 162, 222, 177]]<|/det|>
A 16000 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 162, 390, 177]]<|/det|>
B 32000 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 162, 556, 177]]<|/det|>
C 64000 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 162, 734, 177]]<|/det|>
D 130000 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 208, 650, 223]]<|/det|>
10 The Sun is not the primary source of energy for which resource?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 236, 173, 250]]<|/det|>
A oil

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 261, 191, 276]]<|/det|>
B tidal

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 287, 195, 302]]<|/det|>
C wind

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 314, 201, 329]]<|/det|>
D wave

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 357, 918, 374]]<|/det|>
11 An experiment is done to compare the rate of conduction of thermal energy in metal and plastic spoons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 402, 803, 419]]<|/det|>
An ice cube is placed on one end of each spoon and the other end is heated gently.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 719, 918, 736]]<|/det|>
12 Four students determine the efficiency of four different electrical devices. The teacher knows that one student has made a mistake in the calculation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 763, 454, 782]]<|/det|>
Which value for efficiency is not correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 792, 192, 807]]<|/det|>
A \(12 \%\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 792, 361, 807]]<|/det|>
B \(36 \%\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 792, 526, 807]]<|/det|>
C \(78 \%\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 792, 703, 807]]<|/det|>
D \(102 \%\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 614, 91]]<|/det|>
13 A sample of gas is sealed inside a container of fixed volume.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 451, 120]]<|/det|>
The temperature of the gas is increased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 656, 151]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains why the pressure of the gas increases?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 162, 741, 179]]<|/det|>
A The gas particles collide with the walls of the container more frequently.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 187, 482, 204]]<|/det|>
B The mass of the gas particles increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 213, 606, 230]]<|/det|>
C The number of gas particles in the container increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 238, 631, 255]]<|/det|>
D The time between collisions of the gas particles increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 285, 824, 301]]<|/det|>
14 A student does an experiment to determine the specific heat capacity of a metal block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 314, 460, 330]]<|/det|>
She records the following measurements.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 343, 385, 360]]<|/det|>
energy supplied \(= 12 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 369, 405, 384]]<|/det|>
initial temperature \(= 20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 394, 395, 411]]<|/det|>
final temperature \(= 45^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 421, 421, 436]]<|/det|>
mass of metal block \(= 600 \mathrm{~g}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 451, 554, 467]]<|/det|>
What is the specific heat capacity of the metal block?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 478, 314, 495]]<|/det|>
A \(8.0 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~J} /\left(\mathrm{kg}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 505, 269, 521]]<|/det|>
B \(\quad 0.80 \mathrm{~J} /\left(\mathrm{kg}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 531, 265, 547]]<|/det|>
C \(180 \mathrm{~J} /\left(\mathrm{kg}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 556, 265, 573]]<|/det|>
D \(800 \mathrm{~J} /\left(\mathrm{kg}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 603, 918, 619]]<|/det|>
15 A metal block is left overnight in a cool, shady room. In the morning, the metal block is moved into warm surroundings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 648, 653, 664]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the metal block is correct in the morning?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 675, 554, 692]]<|/det|>
A The internal energy of the metal block increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 701, 537, 717]]<|/det|>
B The temperature of the metal block decreases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 727, 614, 743]]<|/det|>
C Convection transfers energy throughout the metal block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 753, 385, 768]]<|/det|>
D The metal contracts slightly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 798, 918, 815]]<|/det|>
16 A fixed mass of gas is contained within a sealed syringe at a pressure of 100 kPa . The plunger is slowly moved until the pressure is 80 kPa . The final volume of the gas is \(50 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\). The temperature

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 829, 350, 844]]<|/det|>
of the gas does not change.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 857, 609, 874]]<|/det|>
What is the volume of the gas before the plunger is moved?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 884, 228, 901]]<|/det|>
A \(0.25 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 884, 377, 901]]<|/det|>
B \(40 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 884, 543, 901]]<|/det|>
C \(63 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 884, 722, 901]]<|/det|>
D \(160 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|> 17 The diagram shows the more energetic water molecules escaping from the surface of liquid water. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[315, 118, 532, 231]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[516, 136, 557, 151]]<|/det|> key - \(=\) water molecule <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 248, 352, 263]]<|/det|> What is this process called? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 275, 294, 290]]<|/det|> A Brownian motion <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 300, 264, 314]]<|/det|> B condensation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 326, 256, 341]]<|/det|> C evaporation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 352, 247, 366]]<|/det|> D conduction <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 398, 416, 413]]<|/det|> 18 A hot object emits thermal radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 427, 813, 443]]<|/det|> Which row describes two changes that both reduce the rate of emission of radiation? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 456, 567, 583]]<|/det|>
surface area
surface temperature
A
increased
increased
B
increased
reduced
C
reduced
increased
D
reduced
reduced
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 611, 758, 628]]<|/det|> 19 The frequency of a wave is doubled. The speed of the wave does not change. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 642, 498, 658]]<|/det|> What happens to the wavelength of the wave? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 669, 407, 685]]<|/det|> A It becomes four times as large. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 695, 316, 710]]<|/det|> B It does not change. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 722, 239, 736]]<|/det|> C It doubles. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 747, 228, 761]]<|/det|> D It halves. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 793, 490, 809]]<|/det|> 20 Which statement about ultrasound is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 821, 758, 837]]<|/det|> A It has a higher frequency than audible sound and it is a longitudinal wave. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 847, 750, 863]]<|/det|> B It has a higher frequency than audible sound and it is a transverse wave. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 872, 750, 888]]<|/det|> C It has a lower frequency than audible sound and it is a longitudinal wave. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 898, 742, 913]]<|/det|> D It has a lower frequency than audible sound and it is a transverse wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 747, 91]]<|/det|>
21 Which statement about the image produced by a plane mirror is not correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 101, 303, 118]]<|/det|>
A The image is real.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 127, 327, 144]]<|/det|>
B The image is upright.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 154, 493, 169]]<|/det|>
C The image is the same size as the object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 179, 918, 195]]<|/det|>
D The distance from the image to the mirror is the same as the distance from the object to the mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 242, 626, 258]]<|/det|>
22 A ray of light is incident on a boundary between air and water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 271, 671, 287]]<|/det|>
Under which conditions is the ray of light totally internally reflected?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 298, 888, 314]]<|/det|>
A The ray, initially in the air, is incident on the air-water boundary at any angle of incidence.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 324, 921, 340]]<|/det|>
B The ray, initially in the air, is incident on the air-water boundary at an angle of incidence greater than the critical angle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 363, 912, 381]]<|/det|>
C The ray, initially in the water, is incident on the water-air boundary at any angle of incidence.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 390, 918, 407]]<|/det|>
D The ray, initially in the water, is incident on the water-air boundary at an angle of incidence greater than the critical angle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 451, 590, 466]]<|/det|>
23 A converging lens is used to make an image on a screen.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 479, 700, 624]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 640, 496, 656]]<|/det|>
Which type of image is formed on the screen?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 667, 294, 683]]<|/det|>
A real and inverted

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 693, 286, 710]]<|/det|>
B real and upright

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 719, 314, 735]]<|/det|>
C virtual and inverted

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 745, 306, 761]]<|/det|>
D virtual and upright

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
24 A negatively charged rod is brought near to a metal sphere. A positive charge develops on the surface of the metal sphere closest to the negatively charged rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 220, 135]]<|/det|>
Why is this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 146, 708, 163]]<|/det|>
A Electrons in the sphere are attracted by the negatively charged rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 172, 700, 189]]<|/det|>
B Electrons in the sphere are repelled by the negatively charged rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 198, 761, 215]]<|/det|>
C Positive charges in the sphere are attracted by the negatively charged rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 224, 758, 241]]<|/det|>
D Positive charges in the sphere are repelled by the negatively charged rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 269, 769, 286]]<|/det|>
25 The electromotive force (e.m.f.) of a cell is defined in terms of which quantities?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 297, 722, 314]]<|/det|>
A the energy transferred by the cell in moving charge around the circuit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 323, 724, 340]]<|/det|>
B the energy transferred by the cell in moving voltage around the circuit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 349, 714, 366]]<|/det|>
C the power transferred by the cell in moving charge around the circuit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 375, 717, 392]]<|/det|>
D the power transferred by the cell in moving voltage around the circuit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 420, 802, 436]]<|/det|>
26 A resistor of resistance \(R\) is connected to a battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(V\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 451, 399, 466]]<|/det|>
There is a current \(I\) in the resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 480, 421, 497]]<|/det|>
Power \(P\) is dissipated by the resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 511, 419, 526]]<|/det|>
In time \(t\), the energy transferred is \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 540, 358, 555]]<|/det|>
Which expression is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 570, 217, 587]]<|/det|>
A \(E=I V t\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 572, 385, 587]]<|/det|>
B \(E=P I t\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 570, 557, 587]]<|/det|>
C \(P=V I R\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 567, 708, 599]]<|/det|>
D \(P=\frac{V}{R}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 628, 797, 645]]<|/det|>
27 A copper wire of length 80 cm and cross-sectional area \(0.20 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}\) has resistance \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 655, 777, 674]]<|/det|>
Which length of copper wire of cross-sectional area \(0.40 \mathrm{~mm}^{2}\) has resistance \(R\) ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 688, 206, 703]]<|/det|>
A 10 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 688, 372, 703]]<|/det|>
B 20 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 688, 540, 703]]<|/det|>
C 40 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 688, 714, 703]]<|/det|>
D 160 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 905, 91]]<|/det|>
28 Four identical resistors are connected to a battery as shown. Each resistor has a value of \(120 \Omega\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 102, 611, 302]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 314, 314, 330]]<|/det|>
Resistor \(\mathrm{R}_{4}\) is removed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 343, 830, 361]]<|/det|>
Which effect does removing this resistor have on the effective resistance of the circuit?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 372, 498, 388]]<|/det|>
A The effective resistance does not change.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 399, 515, 415]]<|/det|>
B The effective resistance decreases by \(20 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 425, 507, 442]]<|/det|>
C The effective resistance increases by \(20 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 452, 523, 469]]<|/det|>
D The effective resistance decreases by \(120 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 499, 89]]<|/det|> 29 The resistors in the circuit shown are identical. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 103, 419, 120]]<|/det|> The reading on voltmeter \(V_{2}\) is 1.5 V . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 427, 150]]<|/det|> The reading on ammeter \(\mathrm{A}_{2}\) is 0.50 A . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 164, 427, 181]]<|/det|> The reading on ammeter \(\mathrm{A}_{3}\) is 0.25 A . <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 193, 661, 429]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 449, 581, 464]]<|/det|> What are the readings on ammeter \(\mathrm{A}_{1}\) and voltmeter \(\mathrm{V}_{1}\) ? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 476, 504, 603]]<|/det|>
ammeter \(\mathrm{A}_{1} / \mathrm{A}\)
voltmeter \(\mathrm{V}_{1} / \mathrm{V}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 620, 91]]<|/det|>
30 A wire is moved in the region between the poles of a magnet.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[352, 102, 645, 228]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 244, 377, 259]]<|/det|>
A current is induced in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 273, 421, 288]]<|/det|>
In which direction is the wire moved?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 300, 490, 316]]<|/det|>
A horizontally from the N pole to the S pole

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 326, 490, 342]]<|/det|>
B horizontally from the S pole to the N pole

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 501, 368]]<|/det|>
C perpendicularly into the plane of the paper

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 378, 518, 393]]<|/det|>
D perpendicularly out of the plane of the paper

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 423, 918, 439]]<|/det|>
31 A fixed resistor is connected to the secondary coil of a step-down transformer. The transformer is 100\% efficient.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[277, 466, 722, 605]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 618, 869, 633]]<|/det|>
The variable resistor is adjusted so that the current in the fixed resistor decreases by 0.25 A .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 648, 573, 665]]<|/det|>
What is the change to the current in the primary circuit?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 675, 344, 692]]<|/det|>
A It decreases by 0.25 A .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 702, 421, 717]]<|/det|>
B It decreases by less than 0.25 A .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 727, 430, 743]]<|/det|>
C It decreases by more than 0.25 A .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 753, 319, 768]]<|/det|>
D There is no change.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 857, 91]]<|/det|> 32 An electrical device changes the voltage of an electrical supply from 240 V a.c. to 20 V a.c. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 283, 118]]<|/det|> What is this device? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 250, 147]]<|/det|> A a generator <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 158, 211, 175]]<|/det|> B a relay <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 183, 267, 198]]<|/det|> C a transformer <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 209, 250, 224]]<|/det|> D a voltmeter <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 254, 918, 270]]<|/det|> 33 An a.c. generator is set up so that its coil of wire is perpendicular to the magnetic field. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 321, 921, 338]]<|/det|> 36 Which precaution does not always reduce a scientist's exposure when working with sources of ionising radiation? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 365, 827, 382]]<|/det|> A ensuring the scientist only works with sources of radiation that have long half-lives <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 390, 747, 407]]<|/det|> B increasing the distance between the scientist and the source of radiation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 415, 725, 432]]<|/det|> C limiting the time for which the scientist handles the source of radiation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 441, 725, 459]]<|/det|> D placing a lead shield between the scientist and the source of radiation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 486, 866, 503]]<|/det|> 37 A detector is placed near a radioactive isotope and records a count rate of 700 counts / min . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 515, 405, 532]]<|/det|> The half-life of the isotope is 8 min . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 546, 562, 563]]<|/det|> The average background count rate is 60 counts / min . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 575, 627, 593]]<|/det|> What is the count rate measured by the detector after 16 min ? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 603, 289, 620]]<|/det|> A 100 counts / min <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 630, 289, 645]]<|/det|> B 160 counts / min <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 655, 289, 672]]<|/det|> C 175 counts / min <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 681, 289, 698]]<|/det|> D 220 counts / min

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 920, 91]]<|/det|> 38 The nucleus of an isotope of nitrogen, \(N\), absorbs a neutron. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 921, 91]]<|/det|>
40 A student plots a graph of the speed of different galaxies moving away from the Earth against their distance from the Earth.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[135, 118, 860, 355]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 371, 879, 387]]<|/det|>
Using the best straight line shown on the graph, what is the value of the Hubble constant \(H_{0}\) ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 398, 267, 416]]<|/det|>
A \(2.0 \times 10^{-18} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 425, 267, 442]]<|/det|>
B \(2.2 \times 10^{-18} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 452, 250, 469]]<|/det|>
C \(4.5 \times 10^{17} \mathrm{~s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 478, 250, 495]]<|/det|>
D \(5.0 \times 10^{17} \mathrm{~s}\)
